summary: Lymphoma is a cancer of the lymph system, a part of the immune system. It develops from lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell. There are many types, broadly categorized into Hodgkin lymphoma and non-Hodgkin lymphomas. Non-Hodgkin lymphomas arise when T cells or B cells become abnormal and divide uncontrollably, potentially spreading throughout the body. Lymphomas are a part of the broader group of tumors of hematopoietic and lymphoid tissues.
causes: Abnormal T cell or B cell development (for non-Hodgkin lymphoma)

Human T-lymphotropic virus infection (for some non-Hodgkin lymphomas)
symptoms: Feeling of fullness in the abdomen
diagnosis: Biopsy (lymph node biopsy, bone marrow testing)
Imaging (CT scan, PET scan, MRI, ultrasound)
treatments: Therapy to remove proteins from the blood (plasmapheresis)
Watchful waiting (watch and wait, watch and worry)
High-dose chemotherapy followed by autologous stem cell transplantation
Chimeric antigen receptor T cell therapies (e.g., lisocabtagene maraleucel, axicabtagene ciloleucel, tisagenlecleucel, brexucabtagene autoleucel)
subtypes: Large B cell lymphoma, not otherwise specified
Diffuse large B cell lymphoma associated with chronic inflammation
Fibrin-associated diffuse large B cell lymphoma
Extranodal NK/T cell lymphoma, nasal type
Peripheral T cell lymphoma, not otherwise specified
Systemic T cell lymphoma of childhood
